bboxes.raw_text:
BATON ROUGE, La. = A Ne
gro integration leader said he has
given the Louisiana State Uni
versity Board Of Supervisors UNI
til Jan. 27 to decide If it will
admit a Negro to LSUs UNDER
graduate school here.


The Rev. Arthur Jelks said
he had written the board advis-
ing them the case will be turned
over to the legal agency of the
National Association for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People If
they have not acted by then.


Jelks, president of the Baton
Rouge chapter Of the NAACP,
said he was acting on behalf of
Albert James Scott, who was
refused admission to the UNDER
graduate school by LSU Regis
trar Albert Clary. Jelks said
Scott appealed to the NAACP
for legal aid.


Scott, Jelks said, wants to at
tend the universitys summer
school session this year.


The next scheduled meeting
Of the LSU board is Feb. l.


The LSU branch at New Or
leans and the graduate school at
Baton Rouge have been deseg-
regated since the lo50s. The un~
dergraduate school at Baton
Rouge, however, has been closed
to Negroes.


The only known Negro student
to ever enroll at LSU, A. P.
Tureaud Jr., entered the school
under a federal court Injunction
in the fall Of 1858.


Tureaud, the son of New
Orleans attorney, stayed only
eight weeks.

RALEIGH, NC. = An amend
ment to the State Constitution
which opponents said was aimed
at multiplying the voting strength
of the large counties in the State
Legislature, was defeated in
special referendum election,
Tuesday, January IA.


Called the "Little Federal
Amendment" the proposed
measure was actively cam
paigned against by the National
Association for the Advancement
of Colored People.

An NAACP spokesman said the
amendment would have lessened
the power of Negro voters, in a
county like Harnett County, for
example, which has Negro popu-
lation of 80 percent.


Under the present set-up, the
number Of representatives a
county may send to the legisla-
ture is determined by the popu-
lation. Under the defeated amend
ment couties would be represent
ed equally, regardless of popu-
lation.

The Phoenix Gazette and the
Arizona Republic won first and
second place in general excell-
ence category in the 1868 Better
Newspaper Contest spoons ored by
the Arizona Newspaper Associa-
ton. There we're four entries In
this classification of over 1000
daily circulation.


For papers having under 10000
circulation the Scottsdale Daily
Progress won top honors.


The Yuma Daily Sun placed
second and The Mesa Tribune was
third. The CasaGrande Dispatch
was first in general excellence Of
weekly newspapers with circula-
ton over $500.


The Chandler AriZonan was
second and the Arizona Silver
Belt was third. There we're 80
entries.


The Arizona Tribune received
favorable comments from the
Judges, although 1t didn't win an
award.


Remarks included the following
points; very readable, good photo
coerage, excellent news cover
age, and the best content of all
editorial pages.


The Arizona Tribune was listed
first in honorable mention for
editorial excellence. The gram
mer and language and subject
matter of the editorials was
called outstanding. Editorials
were presented in down to earth
manner.


Editorial excellence in daily
papers over 10000 circulation
was won by the. Tucson Daily
Citizen; and by the Casa Grande
Dispatch for weeklies. The Tue
son paper won in the general news
coverage division, too.


The Phoenix Newspapers, Inc,
won top honors for mechanical
excellence and advertising con-
tent.


The Scottsdale Daily Progress
topped all dailies in the editorial
page division.


Two first place awards we're
won by The Arizonian of Scots
dale for mechanical excellence
and advertising content.


Rounding out the weekly
awards, Casa Grande's Dispatch
ranked first for general news
coverage and the News-Sun, of
Sun City. was first for the editor
ial page division.


Community service Awards
we're garnered by the Arizona
Republic for dailies and the Casa
Grande Dispatch for weeklies.

ARIZONA NEWSPAPER
ASSN. 1868 BETTER


NEWSPAPER AWARDS

WASHINGTON - President John
son has endorsed plans for a
national education program de-
signed to make it easier for
Negroes to move into better hom-
es in previously all-white neigh
borhoods.


1t will be carried out with
enforcement of the executive Or
der against racial discrimina-
ton in federally assisted hous-
ing, which will have a broad
er impact during the year as
more housing is affected by its
provisions.


The educational program has
three main aims:


Ito use the committee s
prestige to assist local efforts
to create or expand equal oppor-
tunities in housing.


2-To coordinate and assist
the educational activities Of fed
eral agencies in connection with
the order.


3-To create a climate of un-
derstanding and acceptance of the
idea of equal opportunities and
dispel what the committee con-
siders the fallacy that property
values always go down when Ne
groeS move, In

Johnson OkAYS5
HOUSING ANTI
BIAS PROGRAM

ATLANTA = Nearly IS per-
sons were arrested in two racial
demonstrations in downtown At
lanta after Negro groups picket
ed a restaurant where several Ku
Klux Nansmen were eating.


Members of the Student Nom
violent Coordinating Committee
were demonstrating and several
white persons we're also ar
rested.


The Klansmen we're wearing
their robes when Negroes ap-
peared outside one of the eating
places. The Negroes threw them
selves in front of police wagons
and had to be pulled away.


Police Officer T. R. Pierce
reported he was kicked in the
grion during the scuff1ing.


Calvin Craig, Georgia grand
dragon of the Khan, said his men
stayed inside the restaurant for
two hours because they didn' feel
safe to leave while the Negroes
we're outside.

IS JAILED IN
ATLANTA LUNCH
COUNTER PICKETING

Mr.. and Mrs. James Hobson,
5O15 S. 2lst Street, are the proud
parents of girl born on Jan.
ID

FINAL CHANGE
